title.justification: The title 'Neural Coherence' aptly reflects the core principle being introduced to the field based on the paper's introduction and main content.
title.quote: In this work we develop a principle that we shall refer to as Neural Coherence

extractions.description: The paper introduces Neural Coherence (NC), a method for analyzing the statistics of neural network activation functions across different input sets to improve model generalization in machine learning tasks with limited examples. The NC approach helps in making important decisions regarding early stopping and dataset selection during pre-training, improving the selection of models for out-of-distribution tasks.

type.justification: The paper describes various experiments conducted to validate the effectiveness of Neural Coherence, including checkpoint selection and pre-training data selection, along with performance evaluations and ablation studies.
type.quote: We move on to evaluate the performance Neural Coherence. First, we discuss the methodology and experimental setup, followed by experiments on checkpoint selection, training data selection, and ablation studies.

name.justification: The paper deals with improving model generalization and transfer learning practices in machine learning by introducing the principle of Neural Coherence.
name.quote: In recent years, the practice of using models pre-trained on datasets that are known to generalize well to other tasks has become the de facto standard for attaining high performance on various downstream tasks

name.justification: One of the central themes of the paper is adapting pre-trained models to new tasks using the principle of Neural Coherence to guide different decision processes.
name.quote: Many important machine learning problem settings involve adapting a large pretrained model to a limited number of examples.

name.justification: The paper emphasizes the use of Neural Coherence in guiding checkpoint selection and dataset selection, which are crucial aspects of model selection.
name.quote: We demonstrate the usefulness of neural coherence to guide critical decision during pre-training, such as checkpoint selection and training dataset selection.

name.justification: Neural Coherence is proposed to improve the generalization and performance of models, especially in scenarios where labeled data is scarce.
name.quote: Our experiments indicate that our approach to using Neural Coherence for model selection tasks can significantly improve the performance of deep learning models to out-of-distribution downstream problems.

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions using the ConvNeXt L model in multiple experiments to validate the effectiveness of Neural Coherence.
name.quote: We show that NC can be applied on large, state-of-the-art models such as ConvNeXt L.

is_contributed.justification: The ConvNeXt L model is not introduced as a contribution in this paper; it is used as a benchmark model for the experiments.
is_contributed.quote: We show that NC can be applied on large, state-of-the-art models such as ConvNeXt L.

is_executed.justification: The experiments involving ConvNeXt L clearly mention training and evaluating this model, indicating its execution for validating Neural Coherence.
is_executed.quote: We show that NC can be applied on large, state-of-the-art models such as ConvNeXt L....We train ConvNeXt-L using the setup of the original work [Liu et al., 2022].

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the performance of ConvNeXt L when guided by Neural Coherence principles against several baseline methods.
is_compared.quote: Zero-shot generalization. We investigate the capabilities of NC in a simple zero-shot generalization setting using two pairs of datasets...We observe that NC is significantly outperforming Source-Val, ABE and Target-Val.
